This is a girls appreciating and loving other girls blog
Also I've decided that this AU is a Bechdel Test Passing AU.
I don't know why or how but by god Brienne will find them and she will join them and you know screw it lets let Jeyne Westerling join too
You can never have too many Jeynes
Sandor may or may not last the whole journey lol
summary: In that AU that I never stop talking about--after the death of Ned--Sansa and Arya enter a very deep and very troubling...
caption:
In that AU that I never stop talking about–after the death of Ned–Sansa and Arya enter a very deep and very troubling depression. Meanwhile, on the other side of the city, Jeyne Poole isn’t having a grand ol’ time either.

Eventually, somehow, the girls escape. They take Sandor with them (he goes after them) for protection, and find Jeyne somewhere and take her too, because why not.

blog.name: turtle-paced

summary: Do you think something important near the end is going to hinge on two or more Starks having total blind faith in their family...
question: Do you think something important near the end is going to hinge on two or more Starks having total blind faith in their family bonds and making a giant leap trusting that a sibling is not going betray them? Because that might explain what the show writers were thinking with Sansa & Arya, like they were conscious of the thing where Sansa would never be afraid of Arya & Arya would never think Sansa was trying to elevate herself at the cost of Jon/Bran, but they didn't bother showing that on screen
answer:
I think Stark teamwork and love is going to be vital to the end of the series, yes. They’ve been kept apart so long so that it matters when they get back together, both emotionally and to how the external conflict plays out; Sansa, Arya, and Bran in particular have been getting training montages in three distinct and complementary skillsets. They can do more together than any of them can do apart.

I don’t think highly of how the show’s written Stark relationships in the past few seasons. The constant infighting and hostility, with so little justification, has displayed a real poverty of imagination.

caption: POV Women of ASOIAF part 1/

title: Boyfriend
body:
Arya : Thank you for killing the Night's King, Jaqen ! Now, please, help us rebuild Winterfell !
Jaqen : Help was not promised, lovely girl, only death.
Arya : Fine ! Then you can go kill yourself !
Jaqen : A girl will weep. A girl will lose her boyfriend.
Arya : You're not my boyfriend ! You never even kissed me.
Jaqen : *kisses Arya*
Arya : *gasps* Seven hells...
Jaqen : We have to talk about that boyfriend thing.
Arya : Don't talk just kiss !

blog.name: agameoftragedy
blog.title: Blame GRRM
blog.description: I used to be at least 10% more normal before I read those books. Now everything's Theon Greyjoy (and Robb Stark... and Ramsay Bolton) and everything is awful in a wonderful, wonderful way. My main blog is MzyraJ if you want more of me for some reason.

title: Discussion on Septa Mordane
body:
I find that I’m often loathe to criticise any member of House Stark and their household, I think because of how comparatively wonderful Winterfell was before the plot events start and also how many of them die in fairly short order, but… Septa Mordane. Book!Septa Mordane, I should clarify.

To be fair, we know very little about her - I don’t think we ever even establish which of the kingdoms she originates from, how old she was when she went into becoming a Septa, if she even had a choice… Maybe there are some explanations and excuses hidden there, but I’m going to have to go off of what we know in the books.

She’s essentially a teacher as her main role, and I have a lot of respect for teachers. I understand that it can be very hard to teach children properly when you have like 30 of them in a class and sometimes only for a year, as in mordern schooling. Septa Mordane, however, really only has two of them. And one of those is practically perfect by most accounts.

Honestly, how is she failing Arya this badly? Because not only is Arya not really learning what she’s meant to be, but she’s also seriously undermining her on an emotional level. Yes, Arya is more of a challenge than Sansa on the ladylike skills, but that doesn’t seem to be saying much.

I think Arya is less interested in learning these skills by the time the books begin, and that can make learning slower. It might be that she was never especially interested, perhaps a tomboy from birth. Even if that was the case, I am sure you could find ways to make the skills feel relevant to her - because you really only have two pupils, so you could have one-to-one sessions! Arya says she doesn’t want to be a lady? Alright, but who’s going to fix holes in her clothes for her then - she can learn more practical needlework! Or have her do works she’s more invested in - perhaps a blanket for Nymeria (after all, Nymeria won’t care if it’s not perfect, and practise makes perfect)?

And honestly, I’m not convinced that Arya was like this from birth - I think she’s lost interest because she’s been made to believe that she will never be good at these things (in comparison to Sansa). As she muses in her first chapter:

It wasn’t fair. Sansa had everything. Sansa was two years older; maybe by the time Arya had been born, there had been nothing left. Often it felt that way. Sansa could sew and dance and sing. She wrote poetry. She knew how to dress. She played the high harp and the bells.

Arya’s not dismissing these things; it hurts her that she can’t do them as well as Sansa. And maybe Sansa has natural talent that Arya has observed and envies, but that’s not everything. A caring teacher (who only really has two pupils!) can sit down with her, observe her at her work and see what she’s doing wrong or offer helpful pointers! And feed her interest as above! She’s not so bothered about pretty floral patterns? Do a pattern of direwolves and swords! Not everyone is Sansa! Has Septa Mordane even noticed that Arya’s left-handed? Is that why she struggles so much with some things?

Really, the girl needs her confidence boosted. I expect she may come off as confident because of how she bucks the normal rules, but from in her head we can see how much she’s really struggling with her self-esteem and position in society.

And I imagine Septa Mordane probably feels under pressure - here she is, employed by one of the highest lords of the land to make their daughters into ladies, and she’s only managing 50%! Maybe she feels like she can’t veer outside of the standard lessons and methods in case the parents disapprove, but she’s told Catelyn about Arya’s difficulties, I’m sure if she had ideas to help or fix the situation Cat and Ned could be open-minded (after all, Ned hires Syrio in OTL). They love their daughter, and they believe her getting those skills will be for her overall benefit.


I just… don’t understand how somebody tasked with educating two children (I know it seems like Jeyne Poole and Beth Cassel join in at times, but I doubt they’re a real focus in comparison) can be critically failing one of the two children this ridiculously badly. Like, I’m open to Septa Mordane defenses, but my only conclusion is that she is basically a terrible teacher who is only any good when she is handed pupils with natural aptitude at what she’s meant to be teaching.

At least TV!Septa Mordane gets that moment of defending Sansa, and I maybe wouldn’t put that past her in the books if the occasion arose, but there’s just… so little that really redeems her in the books. Maybe if she had a backstory of just wanting to live in a Motherhouse away from people or that she’s replicating her own education, but… nope.
body_abstract: I find that I’m often loathe to criticise any member of House Stark and their household, I think because of how comparatively wonderful Winterfell was before the plot events start and also how many of them die in fairly short order, but… Septa Mordane. Book!Septa Mordane, I should clarify.

Septa Mordane, however, really only has two of them. And one of those is practically perfect by most accounts.

Honestly, how is she failing Arya this badly? Because not only is Arya not really learning what she’s meant to be, but she’s also seriously undermining her on an emotional level. Yes, Arya is more of a challenge than Sansa on the ladylike skills, but that doesn’t seem to be saying much.

I think Arya is less interested in learning these skills by the time the books begin, and that can make learning slower. It might be that she was never especially interested, perhaps a tomboy from birth. Even if that was the case, I am sure you could find ways to make the skills feel relevant to her - because you really only have two pupils, so you could have one-to-one sessions! Arya says she doesn’t want to be a lady? Alright, but who’s going to fix holes in her clothes for her then - she can learn more practical needlework! Or have her do works she’s more invested in - perhaps a blanket for Nymeria (after all, Nymeria won’t care if it’s not perfect, and practise makes perfect)?

And honestly, I’m not convinced that Arya was like this from birth - I think she’s lost interest because she’s been made to believe that she will never be good at these things (in comparison to Sansa). As she muses in her first chapter:

It wasn’t fair. Sansa had everything. Sansa was two years older; maybe by the time Arya had been born, there had been nothing left. Often it felt that way. Sansa could sew and dance and sing. She wrote poetry. She knew how to dress. She played the high harp and the bells.

Arya’s not dismissing these things; it hurts her that she can’t do them as well as Sansa. And maybe Sansa has natural talent that Arya has observed and envies, but that’s not everything. A caring teacher (who only really has two pupils!) can sit down with her, observe her at her work and see what she’s doing wrong or offer helpful pointers! And feed her interest as above! She’s not so bothered about pretty floral patterns? Do a pattern of direwolves and swords! Not everyone is Sansa! Has Septa Mordane even noticed that Arya’s left-handed? Is that why she struggles so much with some things?

Really, the girl needs her confidence boosted. I expect she may come off as confident because of how she bucks the normal rules, but from in her head we can see how much she’s really struggling with her self-esteem and position in society.

And I imagine Septa Mordane probably feels under pressure - here she is, employed by one of the highest lords of the land to make their daughters into ladies, and she’s only managing 50%! Maybe she feels like she can’t veer outside of the standard lessons and methods in case the parents disapprove, but she’s told Catelyn about Arya’s difficulties, I’m sure if she had ideas to help or fix the situation Cat and Ned could be open-minded (after all, Ned hires Syrio in OTL). They love their daughter, and they believe her getting those skills will be for her overall benefit.


I just… don’t understand how somebody tasked with educating two children (I know it seems like Jeyne Poole and Beth Cassel join in at times, but I doubt they’re a real focus in comparison) can be critically failing one of the two children this ridiculously badly. Like, I’m open to Septa Mordane defenses, but my only conclusion is that she is basically a terrible teacher who is only any good when she is handed pupils with natural aptitude at what she’s meant to be teaching.

At least TV!Septa Mordane gets that moment of defending Sansa, and I maybe wouldn’t put that past her in the books if the occasion arose, but there’s just… so little that really redeems her in the books. Maybe if she had a backstory of just wanting to live in a Motherhouse away from people or that she’s replicating her own education, but… nope.
trail.content_abstract: I find that I’m often loathe to criticise any member of House Stark and their household, I think because of how comparatively wonderful Winterfell was before the plot events start and also how many of them die in fairly short order, but… Septa Mordane. Book!Septa Mordane, I should clarify.
